notesStmt.note:
This edition compares Mitford's manuscript [1825] against the published text of 1834.
Variants are recorded from the manuscript held in the British Library, originally submitted in 1825 to the Examiner's office.

The hand in the manuscript is Mary Russell Mitford's. Mitford tends to write out the full character names, whereas published versions abbreviate. For this variant edition, we are not recording distinctions in delineating the speaker names in the manuscript vs. published version when the speakers are identical.

sourceDesc.bibl:
Charles I: A Tragedy in Five Acts by Mary Russell Mitford London John Duncombe
1834.

supportDesc.condition: Written on the recto sides of the sheets.

handNotes.handNote: In the manuscript of 1825, Mitford's hand numbers the pages of the play in sequence from 1 to 85. A second hand in pencil has renumbered the folio pages for inclusion in this volume of Plays from the Lord Chamberlain's Office, from 415 to 499.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where in the manuscript a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

listChange.change: Overhauled with XSLT the app tagging to make sure all apps contain no more than two rdg elements and all are properly formed. Altered renderings of pb elements to remove these from the critical apparatus (consistent with Eric Hood's encoding in Rienzi). Added note elements, resolved issues marked in XML comments, made several corrections against ms and published copy. Moved comment tags from the TEI header marking our revisions into this change log.
Amended the app markup so it's consistent throughout the play and can be transformed to group all variants in the same app element.
Numbered acts, scenes, prologues, and lines with XSLT.
Checked and corrected all scene heads from published ed. Recoded and added insertion in MS after end of Act III, among other corrections.

div.p: The Scene during part of the first Act is in the Isle of Wight—subsequently in London.

div.head:
Charles the First.
Act the First.

div.stage: Enter Ireton Harrison & Pride, to Downes & Marten.

sp.speaker: Downes.
sp.l: Welcome to London ! dearly welcome
To fair Whitehall! Harrison! Pride! — Where loiters
The valiant General?

sp.speaker: Ireton.
sp.l: He alighted with us
Three hours agone.

sp.speaker: Marten.
sp.l: What three hours here, & still
In harness! Know ye not your coat of mail
Is out of date? Go, doff your armour quick,
Provide ye civil suits, grave civil suits,
Sad reverend civil suits.

sp.speaker: Pride.
sp.l: What mean'st thou?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Seek
Meaning of Harry Marten! Tush! Where tarries
The valiant Cromwell?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: He is busied still
Disposing the tired soldiery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Disbanding
Will be his business soon. The lubbard people,
And the smug citizens, are grown aweary
Of this rough war. Ye must learn gentler trades
If ye would thrive. Peace is the cry, my masters ,
Peace & the King .

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The Newport treaty speeds ,
So far is sure.

sp.speaker: Harrison.
sp.l: But we bring victory
To the good cause. Cromwell hath past careering
From hold to hold, sweeping as with a besom
The foul malignants from the land. The North
Is our's from sea to sea.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave leader
But peace is ever the best victory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In good time comes the General. Valiant Cromwell
Thy praise was on our lips.

sp.speaker: Cromwell.
sp.l: Not mine! not mine!
Praise to the Lord of Hosts whose mighty shield
Bucklered us in the battle ! whose right arm
Strengthened us when we smote! Praise to the Lord!
For his poor instruments, the meanest soldier
Doth his great duty , we no more. My masters
Have ye no news astir? News the prime staple
Of yonder tattling city .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye; the worst
Is that the Commons grow from day to day
of the army, more possessed
By canting Presbyters

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Name not the Commons,
A jealous crew, whose envious hate descends,
'Twixt every pause of fear, on us their loathed
Despised defenders. Were there but one head
To the whole army, they would turn to truth
An elder tyrant's wish, & chop it off.
Despots who prate of liberty!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Worse! worse!
A godless yet intolerant crew, who rear
O'er the down-fallen Church that blacker Idol
A conscience-fettering Presbytery.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir
They shall be quelled. Power, howsoever called,
Is still the subtlest snare the Tempter weaves
For Man's frail sinful soul. Save me from power!
Grant me to follow still a lowly soldier
In the great cause! The Commons shall be quelled.
What other news?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The best is that the King
And the Commissioners draw near a godly
And salutary peace. The King hath bent
His will in a wise humbleness & now—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I joy to hear thee say so. What the Lord
Hath turned his heart, & he hath yielded up
His haughty prelates, his ill counsellors ,
The popish mummery of his Chapel ?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Nay,
Not yet , but he hath promised.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Promised! Oh
The King hath promised!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And ye believe?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Wouldst have us doubters?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: In good sooth not I .
Believe who can! yet ere ye set him free
to the stuffing of his saddle, search
The waste leaves of his prayer book, lest ye find
Some vow to Henrietta, some shrewd protest,
Some ante-dated scroll to throw the shadow
Of a plain lie before his words. Search! search!
It is a prudent King that casts about him
To rid him of his enemies. Search I say.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Why thou art bitter.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Heaven forfend!
I liked Charles Stuart well. I am of the fools
Whom Habit counts amidst her slaves , that love
For old acquaintance sake each long-known pest
And close familiar evil. I liked him well;
The better that his proud disgracious speech
Seemed to my plain & downright simpleness
As honest as mine own. Ye all remember
What friends we were at Holmby. Harrison
And e'en my loving kinsman deemed I waxed
Faint in the cause. But rightly is it written
In the one holy book , Put not thy faith

In Princes.Cromwell refers to the time in 1647 when he and his army held Charles I in palatial captivity at Holmby House in Northamptonshire. In commenting what friends we were may be referring to the considerable attentions provided for the King's comfort even while under military observation.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Yet is he in Carisbrooke
A present danger. Round yon prison Isle
Lurk spies & plots & treasons. Every breeze
Comes pregnant with quick rumours . Every ear
Is bent to listen , Every eye is turned
On those grey walls.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I grant ye. But astir,
Free as the breeze to traverse sea & land,
Creep in our councils, sweep across our camps,
the King harmless then? Yet thou art right;
He's dangerous in Carisbrooke.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Dismiss him;
Send him abroad unkinged; or drive him forth
As Amaziah.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ha! And they slew him !

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What ! send him to seek succour in each court,
From papal Rome to savage Muscovy,
Till he shall burst on us in triumph, heading
Europe's great armament !

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Wert thou a soldier
And in this cause thou would'st cry Welcome, Marten,
To such an armament.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: With His great help.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Aye, with His help , & in this cause, if union
Dwelt in the land. But this is idle talk.
The King is dangerous; dangerous on the throne ;
Dangerous in prison ; dangerous abroad ;
At home & every where . Yet this is idle :
We must abide the Commons' treaty.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Wherefore
Lifts not the army the strong hand of power
Over these stiff-necked rulers? Put them down !
Tread out the firebrands !

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Rather move the Commons
To bring the King to trial.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Who said that?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twas bravely spoken.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Who said that?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The words
like treason.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir, had we met here
To compass such intent, the very thought
Had been a treason. But the words fell straight
Midst our unconscious hearts, unprompted quick
Startling even him who spake them , like the fire
That it the Burning Bush , a sign from Heaven
Direct from Heaven! A comfortable light
To our benighted spirits! As I wrestled
prayer this morning, when I would have cried
For mercy on Charles Stuart, my parched tongue
Clave to my mouth. A token from on high!
A star lit up to guide us!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet the Commons
Will scarcely echo this rapt strain. The King
Hath friends amongst us.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fear not. He who sent
This impulse on his servants, will know how
To turn their hearts.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Ye will not slay the King?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Life hangs not on our lips. Yet surely, Sir,
I hope to spare him. Friends, we must not sleep
Over such stirring business. Downes, go thou
For Bradshaw, that resolved & learned & wise
And godly lawman . Thou art like to find him
At the Guildhall. Say we would speak with him.
Harrison!—Downes went forth as one who loves not
His errand . Lacks he zeal? 'Tis a brave soldier
And yet—Follow him Marten, & return
Bradshaw hither. We shall need thy counsel.
Delay not.
Harrison! thou truest soldier
Of the good cause, to thee we trust the charge
Of guarding our great prisoner. Make thee ready
For a swift journey. I'll confer with thee
Alone, afore thou goest.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Should I not see
The General?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore? Hence !
Nay, Colonel, go not!
I'd speak with thee good Colonel. Rest thee Son.
I'd speak with this good Colonel.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I attend
Your Excellency's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.stage: (walking up & down the room in meditation)
sp.l: Aye the light
Mercurial Harry Marten said but sooth ,
They are unripe for this great charge. It shall be .
And yet—What is the hour?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Upon the stroke
Of one.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: He listens not. & how he searches
The weather with unseeing eyes !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis stormy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Nay a bright day.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: He hears not.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sweep them off
And the whole game is ours , but —Which way blows
The wind?

sp.speaker: Pride.
sp.l: Right from the South .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: It must be ! Shall be!
Ireton I gave thee yesterday a scroll
Of the Malignants in the Commons . Hark ye
The Commons our great masters! If Charles Stuart
Have friends in England there,
'Mid those self-seekers.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Wherefore not arraign
The King before the Council

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir we need
The Commons' name. I would not that our just
And righteous cause lacked any form of law
To startle tender consciences. I have thought
Afore of this. Didst never see the thresher
Winnow the chaff from the full grain? Good Colonel
Thyself shalt play the husbandman to cleanse
This sample of foul corn. Take yonder scroll,
And with a troop of horse go post thy self
Beside the Commons' door, & seize each man
Whose name stains this white parchment. Treat all well
But let none enter.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: And my warrant?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir
My word. If any question, say the General .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Aye the good lord-general
Shall hear of thy good service , fear it not.
Myself shall tell him thy good service, dearer
Than half a dozen battles ,—better worth,
And richlier guerdoned. Haste! Lord Grey of Groby
aid thee to detect the knaves. Away!
Many a goodly manor shall change masters
Tomorrow 'fore the Sequestrators .

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: So!
That work will be well done.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I loathe myself
That I employ the mercenary tool;
But we are in our great aims justified
Our high and holy purpose. Saints & prophets
Have used uncleanly instruments. Good Son
Keep between Fairfax & these men. The weak
Wife-ridden Faintling would demur & dally
And pause at every step, & then draw back —
Unapt for good or ill. He shall know nought.
What make ye here again?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Dost thou not hear?
A mutiny amongst the soldiers.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay,
But half a score malignants, who would fain
Stir up the soldiery.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And they?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: They listen,
But move not.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Seize the traitors. Shoot them dead .
If any murmur still them too. Let death
Follow offence as closely as the sound
Of the Harquebuss the flash. Art thou not gone?
What stops thee?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: more merciful.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why this

Is mercy. If thou saw'st one, match in hand, An anachronism. The chemical match in the modern sense was not invented until 1805, in France. In Cromwell's time, and, indeed, Mitford's youth, a “match” was a variety of other things, including a torch and, as here, a device used to ignite machines of war.
Approach a mine hollowed beneath some rich
And populous town, would'st strike him down at once
Or wait till he had fired the train ?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: At once!
At once!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Well ! —Go thou too fair son! away!
I'll follow on the instant. Look I find
The guilty quiet.
We have been too easy
Yet this swift vengeance
Will strike a wholesome terror, & the echo
May reach to higher miscreants. Good Colonel
Thou loiterest over long. Go block the door
And let none pass , be sure thou let none pass!
I must to yon poor traitors — Let none pass.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Herbert!

sp.speaker: Herbert.
sp.l: My liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Put up my book. I wait
The grave Commissioners, & to be seen
Poring o'er Shakespeare's page—Oh heinous sin!
Inexpiable deadly sin!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Your Grace
Speaks cheerily.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why I have fed my thoughts
On the sweet woodland tale, the lovely tale

Of
Ardenne Arden Forest, till the peaceful end,
The gentle comfortable end, hath bathed
My very heart in sunshine. We are here
Banished as the old Duke, & friends come round,
And foes relent, & calm Forgiveness hangs
An Angel in the air to drop her balm
On all our wounds. I thank thee royal spirit
Thrice princely poet, from whose lightest scene
Kings may draw comfort. Take yon sprig of bay
And lay betwixt the leaves. I marvel much
Where loiter the Commissioners.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Your grace
Hath vanquished them so often that they creep
Fearfully to the field—a beaten foe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: we are near agreed. I have granted more
Than they durst hope for. They set forth to day
Bearing my answer to the Commons. Look
To see a sudden peace ! Many will deem
I have yielded overmuch; but I keep quick
The roots of kingly power, albeit the boughs
Be shrewdly lopped . And then to see again
My wife, my children ! to reward my poor
And faithful servants ! to walk free! to reign!
Look to see sudden peace.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Heaven speed the day!
Yet, Sire, forgive my fear, would thou hadst ta'en
The proffered means of safety, had escaped
This Island prison!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What! when I had pledged
My word, my royal word! Fie , fie, good Herbert!
Better if danger were a thousand fold
Perish even here than forfeit that great bond
Of honour a King's word. Fie! Fie!—Yet sooth
Thou mean'st me kindly Herbert.—Ha. the Sea
That day & night hath chased so angrily
Breaking around us with so fierce a coil,
An elemental warder, smiles again,
Merrily dancing in the cold keen light
Of the bright wintery sun . We shall have boats
From England.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: One hath landed, Sire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And they
May bear my message without pause. Who comes?

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: May't please you, Sire, the high Commissioners
Crave audience of your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Admit them.
sp.stage: Lord Salisbury, Lord Say, Sir Harry Vane, & other Commissioners, some of them Ministers.
sp.l: See ! Vane hath lost his frown. We shall have peace.
Good morrow my good Lord of Salisbury!
Lord Say, Sir Harry Vane, & gentles all
A fair good morrow. The sun smiles at last
Upon our meeting.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Sunshine after storm !
A happy bodement Sire; a type of peace.

sp.speaker: Salis.
sp.l: Yet clouds are gathering.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Tush! the noon-day sun
Will overcome them.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.l: Cease this heathenish talk
Of omens. Hath your grace prepared your answer
To the proposals of the Commons?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Reach
Yon paper Herbert. Set ye forth today ?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.l: With the next tide.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So speed ye wind & wave
And send ye swiftly hence & swiftlier back
Blest messengers of peace, winged like the dove
That bore the olive token ! Take my answer,—
A frank compliance with each Article
Save twain, save only twain.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: And they—I prithee
Be wholly gracious Sire! Peril not thus
Your country's weal, your freedom, & your crown
By timeless reservation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have yielded
Power & prerogative & state & wealth
For my dear country. All that was mine own,
All that was mine to give I freely gave,—
That I withhold is of the conscience. Look
these white hairs, and think if one so signed
Marked for the grave, may for the vain respect,
Of crowns or kingdoms offer up his friends
Or his old worship. Mark me I'll not yield
man of that devoted seven, nor bate
A word of my accustomed prayer, to save
My limbs from cankering fetters, or win back
That velvet prison a throne. No more of this.
Bear ye my treaty, Sirs, & use but half
That goodly gift of eloquence for me
That ye to me have shewn, & be but heard
With half the grace,
Subject & King, in peace, in blessed peace.
Whoso asks entrance with so wild a din?
Give him admittance quickly.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.l: Yet my liege
For these seven Cavaliers —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more! No more!
Thou hast my answer. By the iron tread
A soldier.

sp.speaker: Salis.
sp.l: Harrison! What brings thee here ?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A sad and solemn message to your prisoner.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Speak out thy tidings , speak thine errand, Sir,
I am strong-hearted ,—sovran privilege
Of them that tower so high ,—Strong as yon eagle
That nests amongst the cliffs. I have borne loads
That would have sunk a meaner man in gulphs
Of deep despair. Thine errand !—Stop!—Who sent thee?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The Commons

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now thine errand.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: To demand
body of Charles Stuart, sometime King
Of England .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sometime King !

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Whom I attach
treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Treason & the King! Off Sir
I warn thee touch me not. Some natures feel
A shuddering loathing at cold-blooded worms,
Snakes, aspics, vipers, toads, flesh doth creep
And shiver if the reptile man approach
Too closely. Shew thy warrant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Look you, Sir,
The warrant be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.l: Dost thou not see
The master-hand of Cromwell in this deed?
Where is the General?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Come victorious home—
Knowst thou not that?—to lend his pious aid
To our great work.

sp.speaker: Salis.
sp.l: But thou art from the Commons,
Not from the Council —sure thou saidst the Commons!—
And they were earnest for the treaty.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Aye
But in that goodly field grew tares, rank tares,
Which have been weeded out . Stiff presbyters,
Bitter malignants, & those sons of wrath
That falter in the better path, dead boughs
Upon a noble tree. Some fifty horse
Swept off the rubbish.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: But the men are safe?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Even as thyself.
Now, sir, hast thou enough
Studied yon parchment?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Treason! to arraign
A crowned King of treason! I am here
with these same Commons on the faith,
The general faith of nations. I appeal
To ye, my foes; to thee, my gaoler. What!
Stand ye all mute , high lords & learned lawmen
And reverend ministers? Ye had glib tongues
For subtle argument & treasonous craft,
cobweb sophistry. Have ye no word
For faith, for honour? Not one word? Shame! Shame!

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.l: We are the Commons' servants, & must needs
Obey their mandate .

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Yet with grief of heart—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Silence!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye silence! Sir I thank thee yet
That sparest me that sharpest injury
A traitor's pity. For that gentle deed
I yield me gently to thy hands. Lead on
Where'er thou wilt I follow.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Straight to London.
To bide thy trial.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What! Will they dare that?
Doth not the very thought, the very word
Appal the rebels? Trial! When we meet
Confronted in that regal hall , the King
And his revolted subjects, whoso then
Shall be the judge? The King! Whoso make inquest?
Whoso condemn? And whoso fling a pardon,
A scornful pardon on your heads? The King!
The King! I tell ye Sirs. Come on! I pant
To meet these judges . For ye, solemn mockers,
Grave men of peace, (deceivers or deceived,
Or false or true boots little) fare ye well!
Yet give me yon vain treaty . Now, by Heaven
I shame to have communed with ye! This slight paper
That shivers at a touch is tough & firm
Mated with such as ye. Bear to the Commons,
Your masters, yon torn fragments, fitting type
type
Of ye, men of a broken faith! Farewell!
Now Sir I wait thee.

div.head:
Charles the First.
Act the Second.

div.stage: The Painted Chamber. A table with the Commissioners lawyers & c seated. A gothic window behind the table through which objects that pass may be seen.
Bradshaw, Fairfax, Ireton, Downes, Cook, Marten Tichburn & c. Fairfax comes forward, followed by Bradshaw Ireton & Downes .

sp.speaker: Fairfax.
sp.l: Soon as the day be fixed —apprise me Sirs
The Halberdiers shall wait ye.

sp.speaker: Bradshaw.
sp.l: Good my lord
Thou wilt not leave us? When did Fairfax fly
A post of danger? And his honoured name
Stands foremost in our roll.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Sir I am sworn
The soldier of the Commons, & as soldier
Obey them loyally. All that ye need
For state or for defence in this sad pageant
Our camp shall furnish. Save their General
You may command the army. For this trial
I like it not. I am no gownsman. Sir
The Halberdiers shall wait ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: a nice
And peevish conscience Fairfax bears! Will send
Arms horses men to escort the prisoner, line
The Court, defend the Judges , guard the scaffold—
If so our wisdom wills—yet hold himself
Content & harmless so his single voice
Swell not the general doom.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Yet 'tis a wise
And noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Tush! a good sword blade !
Keen in the field, but at the Council dull
And heavy as as the scabbard.
Lo! where comes
One whose bright spirit knows no dimness. Cromwell!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Hear ye the news my masters? Harrison
That bold and zealous soldier of our Israel
Is here.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The King of Kings A New Testament epithet for Christ, who is called the King of Kings in Revelations 17:2 (the Lamb shall overcome them: for he is Lord of lords, and King of kings.) See also Revelations 19:16.
Delivers him unto us. Harrison
Awaits his landing. We must be prepared
For instant trial. Glad am I & proud
To greet with looks so firm & confident
This full & frequent council.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Yet you met
A great one who forsakes us.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Lord-General ?
Why on the battle-day such loss might cause
An hour's perplexity. Now—Hark ye, Sirs!
Passing awhile Lord Fairfax ' door I saw
The Queen.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: In England! Didst thou see her face?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No ! but I knew her by the wanton curls,
The mincing delicate step of pride, the gait
Erect and lofty. 'Twas herself, I say,
Vain Jezabel !

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: At Fairfax ' gate! Alas
Poor lady!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ha! And must we watch thee too?
No word of this good Sirs !
Why master Cook
What needs this long I ndictment? Seems to me
Thou dost mistake our cause. The crime is not
A trivial larceny, where some poor thief
Is fenced & hemmed in by a form of words
In tedious repetition, endless links
chain of law, lest at some loophole
The paltry wretch escape. We try a King,
In the stern name of Justice. Fling aside
These cumbering subtleties, this maze of words,
And in brief homely phrase, such as the soldier
May con over his watchfire, or the milkmaid
Wonderingly murmur as she tends her kine,
Or the young boy trace in his first huge scroll,
sew in her sampler, say
That we arraign Charles Stuart King of England
For warring on his people. Let this deed
Be clear & open as beseems the men
On whom the Lord hath set his seal. Besides
That will let loose thy stream of eloquence
by this cold freezing plea. What says
Our learned President .

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Thou art right ! Thou art right.
Our fair intent needs not a veil. Be sure
He shall have noble trial & speedy, such
As may beseem a King.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: What is his bearing?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Resolved & confident. Last night at Windsor
Eating a Spanish melon of choice flavour
He bade his servant, Herbert, send the seeds
To be sowed straight at Hampton.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Many men
Plant acorns for their successors . This King sets
A gourd.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The prophet's gourd. We are all mortal.
Sow but a grain of mustardAn allusion to the New Testament parable of the mustardseed (Matthew 17:20), the green thing
That soonest springs from death to life, & thou
Shalt wither ere the leaflets shoot.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The King
Deems that we dare not try him.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Dare not! Cromwell
How soon dost think—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Was't not the plash of oars?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Cromwell!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: He hears thee not. His sense rejects
All sounds save that for which with such intense
And breathless zeal he listens. See his cheek
Quivers with expectation. Its old hue
Of ruddy brown is gone.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Hark! hark! my masters!
is come! He is come! We are about to do
A deed which shall draw on us questioning eyes
From the astonied nations. shall gaze
Afeared & wondering on this spot of earth
As on a comet in the Heavens, fatal
To Kings of old. Start ye? Why at the first
started, as a man who in a dream
Sees indistinct & terrible grim forms
Of Death & Danger float before his glazed
And powerless eyes:— but then as one who wakes
The inspiring light fell on me, & I saw
The Guiding Hand of Providence visibly
Beckoning to the great combat. We are His soldiers
Following the Cloud by day, the Fire by night
And shall we not be constant? We are arrayed
Against the stiff combined embodied spirits
Of prelacy & tyranny —Shall we not
Be bold?
See! See! He passes. So shall pass
The Oppressor from the earth. His very shadow
The very traces of his foot are gone
And the English ground is free, the English air
Free, free .—All praise be to His Mighty Name !
This is the crowning work.

div.stage: Scene—A gallery near the King's prison .
The Queen, Lady Fairfax, a Centinel.

sp.speaker: Lady Fairfax.
sp.l: Another guard! The pass-word that hath served us
Through court & gate & hall will fail us here,
This is the immediate prison of the King.
Say, royal Madam, had we best accost
Yon centinel?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: The prison of the King!
And I have lived to hear those words, that pierce
daggers, spoken familiarly
As she would say Good den, or Fare ye well!
The prison of the King! England hath been
His prison , but this one leads —My lady Fairfax
Command him to admit us.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: He draws nigh.

sp.speaker: Centinel.
sp.l: Fair mistresses how won ye here? This gallery
Leads to the prisoner's chambers.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We would see him.
Admit us !

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Be ye frenetic? Know ye not
That save the Lords Commissioners none dare
Approach the prisoner?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Say the King.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Who art thou
That speak'st with such command?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: me Knowst thou not me? me
Thy General's wife ?

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: I am of Cromwell's soldiers
And own no woman's rule.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Admit us slave
I am the Queen, thy Queen, the Queen of England ,
Make way !

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: Stand back I say.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: am a wife
Seeking her husband in his prison ! Soldier
If thou have a man's heart!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Here's money for thee
Admit her.

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: I have fought in twenty fields,
A Veteran of the cause. Put up thy gold;
And, Madam , please you home!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Here is my home
My husband's prison gate —I'll live here, die here;
without, as he within,
Till Death the great Deliverer comes to free
The Captives; this shall be my grave. Charles!Charles!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Peace! peace !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I thought I heard him. Charles! My Charles!
My King! My husband !

sp.speaker: Cent.
sp.l: There are many chambers
Between thee & the King. I prythee hence.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Madam take patience.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Charles! He must be dead
Already that he answers not.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: What means
This clamourous din of female tongues so near
The prison of the King? The lady Fairfax!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Cromwell!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Queen!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Cromwell ! ! thee
Yet open yonder door & I'll pray for thee
All my life long. That churlish centinel—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: duty.— her to her husband.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Be quick! Be quick!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The word is Naseby.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: On
Be quick ! Be quick!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Now my good lady Fairfax !
Right well beseemeth christian charity
To succour them that suffer , howsoe'er
'Mid strict professors it may breed some marvel
That one so famed for rigid sanctity,
The gravest matron of the land, should herd
With yonder woman.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: the Queen?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: A papist;
A rank Idolater; a mumming masquer;
A troller of lewd songs; a wanton dancer;
A vain upholder of that strength of Satan
The Playhouse . They that be so eminent
As thou will find maligners . 'Tis the curse
Of our poor fallen nature. Be not seen
Hovering about these walls. I speak in love
Of the lord-general .

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: The lord-general ,
And many a godly minister, & I,
Weak woman though I be, mourn that these walls
Should come between the King & people. Peace
Had been a holier bond.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Peace! that our General
The good lord Fairfax, Captain of the guard,
May tend the popish ladies to their mass
A high promotion! Peace! That every dungeon
May swarm with pious ministers they
Their old oppressions? Peace! That the grave matron
The lady Fairfax may with troubled thoughts
Sit witness of lewd revels; —mock & scorn
Of the light dames of the chamber & the lordlings
Their gallants ,—popinjays, who scoff & jeer
At the staid solemn port, the decent coif,
The modest kerchief —I have heard such jibes—
When the gay Queen hath laughed

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: What! Hath she dared
Vain minion!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And to see thee with her! Thou
That shouldst have been a Jael in this land,
A Deborah, a Judith .

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Nay we live
Under a milder law. Whate'er their crimes
Urge not this bloody trial.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Whoso saith
That the trial shall be bloody? He who reads
All hearts He only knows how my soul yearns
Toward yonder pair. I seek them now, a friend,
With friendly proffers. As we reach thy coach
I'll tell thee more. Come Madam !

div.stage: The scene opens & shews the King's Apartment

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Herbert!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: An please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go seek
The General.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Fairfax?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cromwell! Cromwell! Say
The King commands his presence.
To forerun him;
To plunge at once into this stormy sea
Of griefs ; to summon my great foe ; to front
The obdurate Commons, the fanatic army
Even the mock Judges , they who dare to reign
Over a King — to breast them all! Then trial,
Or peace! Death or the crown! Rest comes with either
To me & England, comfortable rest
After my many wanderings.
Henrietta!
My wife, my Queen, is't thou? Is't not a dream?
For I have dreamed so & awakened—Heaven
Shield me from such a waking! Is't a truth?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Do not my tears give answer? Did that vision
Rain drops of joy like these?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To see thee here
Is to be young & free again, again
A bridegroom & a King.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ever my King!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have heard nothing like that voice of hope
Since we were parted !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Wherefore dost thou pause?
Why gaze on me so mournfully?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art pale, my Henrietta, very pale;
And this dear hand that was so round & fair
Is thin & wan, Oh very wan!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: 'Twas pining
For thee that made it so. Think on the cause,
And thoult not mourn its beauty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And this grief,
Will kill her! Joined to any other man
She might have lived on in her loveliness
For half an age —She's mine, & she must die.
Oh this is a sad meeting! I have longed
Have prayed to see thee !—Now—Would thou wert safe
In France again, my Dear-One !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Say not so ,
I bring thee comfort safety. Holland, France
Are firmly with thee; save the army all
This rebel England is thine own; & e'en
Amid the Army some the greatest, some
That call themselves Thy Judges;— 'Tis the turn
Of Fate, the reflux of the tide.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Forget not
That I'm a prisoner, sweet-one, a foredoomed
Discrowned prisoner. As erewhile I passed
Sadly along, a soldier in his mood
Spat on me ; none rebuked him, none cried shame,
None cleft the coward to the earth ,—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh traitors!
Oh sacrilegious rebels! Let my lips
Wipe off that scorn ! My Charles thou shalt resume
Thy state, shalt sit enthroned a judge a King
Even in the solemn hall , the lofty seat
Of their predestined treason. For thy life
It is assured—Lord Broghill & a band
Of faithful Cavaliers—But thou shalt reign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost thou remember Cromwell? Ere thou quittedst
England , , he was most like the delving worm
Hypocrisy; that slough is cast, & now
His strong & shining wings soar high in air
As proud ambition. First demand of him
What King shall reign.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He is my trust.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hast seen him?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He sent me to thee now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha ! W herefore ? But I've learnt to trust in nought
Save Heaven. Since thou art here I am content
To live & reign, but all in honour. I'll
Renounce no creed, resign no friend, abandon
No right or liberty of this abused
Misguided people ,—no! nor bate one jot

Of the old prerogative, my
privilege,
The right divine of Kings. Death were to me
As welcome as his pleasant evening rest
To the poor way worn traveller, & yet
I fain would live for thee— cheer up fair wife!
Would live for love & thee. Hast seen thy children?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Not yet. They say Elizabeth whose face
Even when a little child resembled thine
To wonder, hath pined after thee & fed
Her love by thinking on thee, till she hath stolen
Unconsciously thy mien & tone & words
Of patient pensiveness , a dignity
Of youthful sorrow, beautiful & sad.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor child! poor child! a woeful heritage!
When I have gazed on the sweet seriousness
Of her young beauty, I have pictured her
In the bright May of life, a Queenly bride,
Standing afore the altar with that look
Royal & calm & pure as the azure skies
Now
Cromwell!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Did'st thou desire my presence?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I sent for thee
To bear my message to thy comrades.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir,
I wait your pleasure. I would welcome you
Unto this goodly city—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Doth the Gaoler
Welcome his prisoner? I am Charles Stuart,
And thou—Now shame on this rebellious blood!
I thought that it was disciplined & schooled
Into proud patience. Let me not appear
Discourteous . Sir the King is bounden to thee.
Now hear mine errand.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: First hear me!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Queen

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Fie! doff this strangeness, when it was thyself
That sent me hither . Cast aside the smooth
Obedient looks that hide thy thoughts, be plain
honest .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I have ever been so.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Open in speech & heart even as myself
When I, thy Queen, hold out the hand of peace
And amity, & bid thee say what title
The King shall give to his great General.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: None.
Thou badst me answer plainly.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet thou wast
Ambitious once.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Grant that I were,—as well
I trust I had more grace,—but say I were so,
Thinkst thou not there be homely names which sound
As sweetly in men's ears? Which shall outlive
A thousand titles in that book of fame
History? All praise be to the Lord I'm not
Ambitious.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Chuse thine office. Keep the name
Thy sword hath rendered famous. Be l ord Vicar ,
Be Captain of the Guard . Forbid this trial—
Thou canst an if thou wilt—be Charles's friend,
And second man of the Kingdom .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Second! Speakst thou
These tempting words to me? I nor preside
O'er Court or Parliament; I am not, Madam,
Lord General of the Army. Seek those great ones —
My place is in the ranks. Wouldst thou make me
The second in the kingdom? Seek those great ones —
The second!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou, & well thou know'st it Cromwell,
Art the main prop of this rebellion. General
Lord President what are they but thy tools,
Thy puppets, moved by thy directing will
As chessmen by the skilful player ? 'Tis thou
That art the Master Spirit of the Time
Idol of people & of army, leader
Of the fanatic commons , judge,
Of this unrighteous cause.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And she would make me
The second man of the kingdom! Thou but troublest
Thyself & me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet hear me but one word !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No more of bribes —thou badst me to speak plainly,—
Thou hast been bred in courts & deemest them
Omnipotent o'er all ; but I eschew
The Mammon of Unrighteousness.—I warn ye
Ye shall learn faith in one man's honesty
Before ye die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Never in thine . At Holmby
We trusted . Fool to think—'Twas not in fear—
I dread thee not. Thou dar'st not try the King.
The very word stands as a double guard,
A triple armour, a bright shield before him;
A sacred halo plays around the head
Anointed & endiademmed , a dim
Mysterious glory. Who may dare to call
For justice on a King? Who dare to touch
The crowned & lofty head?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Was it at Hardwicke
Or Fotheringay —fie on my dull brain!—
the fair Queen of Scots, the popish woman,

The beautiful, his Grandame, died?Mitford's Cromwell is confused over where Mary Queen of Scots was immprisoned and executed, an historical event that of course foreshadows the events of King Charles's imprisonment, trial, and regicide. His mention of Hardwicke seems to refer to Hardwick Hall, built by Bess of Hardwick (or Elizabeth Talbot), but the queen was never held here. Likely Mitford is referring through Cromwell to the period when Mary Queen of Scots was held captive at Sheffield Castle and Manor Lodge, guarded by George Talbot, the Sixth Earl of Shrewsbury and his wife, who was Bess of Hardwick. Bess befriended the Queen during this period of captivity.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: A Queen
A vain & envious woman, yet a Queen,
Condemned Queen Mary. Ye are subjects, rebels,
Ye dare not try your King; all else ye may do;
All else ye have done; fought, imprisoned, chased,
Aye tracked & hunted, like that pious Henry
The last of the red-rose, whom visiting
Helpless in prison, his arch enemy
The fiendish Richard slew;—even as perchance—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Shame on thy slanderous tongue! There lies my sword.
Didst take me for a murderer? Royal Madam Harken, Madam,

When thou
shalt speak again of Henry's fate,
Remember 'twas the restless shrew of Anjou
That drove her gentle husband to his end.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take up the sword ! and wife I prythee peace!
I yet am King enough to end these brawls.
Take up thy sword! —Albeit my breast be bare
him, he'll not strike ,
That were an honest murder. There be ways
Stiller & darker; there be men whose craft
Can doom with other tongues ; with other hands
Can slay. —I know thee Sir.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I would not slay
A sinner unprepared.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go to! I know thee.
Say to the Parliament that I demand
A conference ; lords & Commons.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir the Commons
Will grant no conference. Thou must address thee
To the High Court of Justice, to thy Judges .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh vain & shallow treason! Have ye not
The King's high court? the Judges of the land?
I own no other. Yet if they—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Expect
Nothing of them but Justice. I came to thee
As to a brother, in pure charity,
In meek & christian love, when these sharp taunts
Arose betwixt us. Still I fain would save thee —
Resign the crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Oh vanity
Of man's proud heart! Cling to that sinful toy,
A sound, an echo, a dim shadow weakening
As the true substance flies to that word,
And cast away thy life!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold Henrietta!
What dost thou ask me for so poor a boon
As life to change fair Honour? I've a son
A gallant princely boy— Wouldst have me yield
The old ancestral crown his heritage
For the small privilege to crawl awhile
On this vile earth, mated with fouler worms
Than they that feed below? Wouldst have me sell
My Kingdom for a little breath?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thy Kingdom!
Thou hast not a strong hold left.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have one here.
know'st my answer.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet if there be danger—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, dearest, peace! Is the day fixed?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The day,
The very hour is set. At noon tomorrow,
Heaven permitting !

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The decrees of Heaven
Be oft to man's dark mind inscrutable .
The lightning flame hath scorched the straw-thatched roof
Of harmless cottagers, hath rent the spire
Of consecrated temples, hath struck down
Even the dumb innocent oak that never lied,
Never rebelled, never blasphemed. A veil
Hangs before Heaven's high purpose ; yet when man
Slays man, albeit no King, a reckoning comes.
A deep & aweful reckoning. I'll abide
The trial.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: At thy peril.

div.head:
Charles the First
Act the Third.

div.stage: Scene—Westminster Hall fitted up for the King's trial—

Bradshaw, seated as President;—Cromwell, Ireton, Harrison, Downes, Marten, Millington, & other Judges on benches;—Cook & other lawyers clerks &c. at a table;—The Queen & the Lady Fairfax veiled, with other ladies in a gallery;—a chair of state on one side for the King;—the whole stage filled with spectators guards &c.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Hath every name been called? And every Judge
Appeared at the high summons?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.l: Good my lord
Each one hath answered.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Is wanting still.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Fair son,
We have enow of work—Doth not yon cry
Announce the prisoner?—enow of work
For one brief day without him.—Downes sit here,
Beside me man !—We lack not waverers,
Men whose long doubts would hold from rosy dawn
the slow lighting of the evening star
In the clear Heaven of June. Of such as they
were too many. How say'st thou good Downes?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Even as thou say'st.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Yet 'tis a godly General—
A valiant & a godly . Ha! the prisoner!

div.stage: Enter King Charles, attended by Herbert & other servants, Hacker & guards.
The Soldiers &c as the King walks to his Chair cry Justice! Justice!

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.l: Peace! Silence in the Court.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Ye shall have justice.
My lords Commissioners, whilst I stood pausing
How fitliest to disclose our mighty plea,
Dallying with phrase & form, yon eager cry
Shot like an arrow to the mark, laying bare
The very core of our intent. Sirs, we
Are met to render justice, met to judge
In such a cause as scarce yon ardent sun
That smiles upon us from his throne hath seen
Since light was born. We sit to judge a King
Arraigned by his own people; to make inquest
Into the innocent blood which hath been spilt
Like water; into crime & tyranny,
Treason & murder. Look that we be pure
My brethren! that we cast from out our hearts
All blinding passions ;—Fear that blinks & trembles
At shadows ere they come; Pride that walks dazzled
In the light of her vain glory ; feeble Pity
Whose sight is drowned in tears; & grim Revenge
Her fierce eyes sealed with gore. Look that we chase
hidden sin,
Each meaner virtue from our breasts, & cling
To Justice, only Justice. Now for thee
Charles Stuart King of England . Thou art here
To render compt of awful crimes, of treason
Conspiracy & murder. Answer!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: First
May it please you hear the charge .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stop . Who are ye
That dare to question me?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Thy Judges.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say
My subjects. I am a King, whom none may judge
On earth. Who sent ye here .

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The Commons.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What!
Be there no traitors, no conspirators,
No murderers, save Kings, that they dare call
Stern Justice down from Heaven? Sir I fling back
The charge upon their heads, the guilt the shame,
The eternal infamy,—on them, who sowed
The tares of hate in fields of love; who armed
Brother gainst brother, breaking the sweet peace
Of country innocence, the holy ties
Of Nature breaking, making war accurst
As that Egyptian plague the worst & last
When the First-born were slain. I have no answer
sp.note: References the plagues in the Old Testament Book of Exodus, chapters 11-12, brought upon the Eqyptians to convince the Pharoah to release the Israelites from slavery. In the final plague, the Egyptians' first-born sons are killed by divine vengeance while the homes of the Israelites are passed over and their sons escape.
sp.l: For them or ye. I know ye not.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Be warned;
to the accusation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will die
A thousand deaths, rather than by my breath
Give life to this new court against the laws
And liberties of England.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: we know
Your love of liberty & England. Call
The witnesses. Be they in court?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: They wait
Without.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Send for them quickly. Once again
King wilt thou plead?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast my answer . Never.

div.stage: (A pause of a few moments, during which the head of the King's staff, on which he was leaning falls and rolls across the stage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What fell? The breathless silence of this vast
And crowded court gives to each common sound
A startling clearness. What hath fallen?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The head
Of the King's staff. See how it spins and bounds
Along the floor, as hurrying to forsake
The royal wretch its master. Now it stops
At Cromwell's feet—direct at Cromwell's feet.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The toy is broken

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What is the device?
Some vain idolatrous image?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No, a crown ,
A golden crown, a hollow glittering crown,
Shaped by some quaint & cunning goldsmith. Look
what a reed he leans, who props himself
On such a bauble !

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: It rolled straight to thee;
If thou wast superstitious—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Pass the toy
On to the prisoner ; he hath faith in omens—
I— Fling him back his gew-gaw.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: We wait too long.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: My Lord the witnesses—

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Call any man. Within our bleeding land
There lives not one so blest in ignorance
As not to know this treason ; none so high
But the storm overtopped him; none so low
But the wind stooped to root him up. Call any
The Judge upon the bench, the Halberdier
That guards the door.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Aye?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: No need to swear him ! He hath ta'en already
The Judge's oath.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Judge's oath, not this.
Omit no form of guardian law ; remember
The life of man hangs on our lips.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Smooth traitor!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Lieutenant General Cromwell wast thou present
In the great fight of Naseby?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Was I present!
Why I think ye know that. I was.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: see
The prisoner in the battle?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Many times.
He led his army, in a better cause
I should have said right gallantly. I saw him
First in the onset, last in the retreat.
That justice let me pay the King.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Raised he
His banner 'gainst his people? Didst thou see
royal standard in the field?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: My lord
It rose full in the centre of their host
Floating upon the heavy air.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: The arms
Of England?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Aye ; the very lion-shield

That waved at
Cressi Crécy
& at
Azincourt Agincourt
Triumphant. None may better know than I
For it so pleased the Ruler of the Field,
The Almighty King of Battles, that my arm
Struck down the Standard-Bearer, & restored
The English lion to the lion hearts
Of England.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Please you, Sir, retire. Now summon—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call not another. What I have done boldly
In the face of day & of the nation, that,—
Nothing repenting, nothing derogating
From the King's high perogative,— boldly
As freely I avow—to you—to all men !
I own ye not as Judges. Ye have power
As pirates or land robbers oer the wretch
Entrapped within their den ; a power to mock
Your victim with a form of trial, to dress
Plain murder in a mask of Law . As Judges
I know ye not.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Enough that you confess
The treason—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stop . Sir I appeal to them
Whence you derive your power.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The people? King
Thou seest them here in us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh that my voice
Could reach my loyal people! That the winds
waft the echoes of this groined roof
So that each corner of the land might hear,
From the fair Southern vallies to the hills,
The wild hills of my native North, from the shores
Of the great Ocean to the channeled West,
Their rightful Monarch's cry. Then should ye hear
From the universal nation, town and plain,
Forest & village, the stern aweful shout
Of just deliverance, mighty & prolonged,
Deafening the earth & piercing Heaven, & smiting
Each guilty conscience with such fear as waits
On the great Judgment-Day. The wish is vain—
Oh vainer than a dream! I & my people
Are over-mastered. Yet, Sir, I demand
A conference with these masters. Tell the Commons
The King would speak with them.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: We have no power
To stay the trial.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord, perchance
The King would yield such reason as might move
The Commons to renew the treaty. Best
Confer with them.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Art mad?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: 'Tis ye are mad
Who drive with a remorseless haste this work
Of savage butchery onward. I was mad
That joined ye.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: This is sudden.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: He's our King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Our King! Have we not faced him in the field
An hundred times? Our King! Downes, hath the Lord
Forsaken thee? Our King! Why I have seen thee
Hewing through mailed Battalia till thy sword
And thy good arm were dyed in gore to reach
Yon man. Didst mean to save him? Listen, Sir ;
I am thy friend —'Tis said— I lend no ear
To slanderers, but this tale was forced upon me—
'Tis said that one, whose grave & honoured name
Sorts ill with midnight treachery, was seen
Stealing from the Queen's lodging thy friend,
Thy fast friend — We oft see in this bad world
The shadow Envy crawling stealthily
Behind fair Virtue hold all for false
Unless thou prove it true friend
But if the Sequestrators heard this tale—
Thou hast broad lands. —(aloud) Why do ye pause?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: My high
honouring task to plead at this great bar
For lawful Liberty, for suffering Conscience ,
For the old guardians of our rights, the Commons,
Against the lawless fiend Prerogative,
The persecuting Church, the tyrant King
Were needless now & vain : the haughty prisoner
Denies your jurisdiction. I call on ye
For instant judgment.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Sir, for the last time,
I ask thee — wilt thou plead?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have I not answered?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Your judgment, good my lord !

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: All ye who deem
Charles Stuart guilty, rise!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What all!

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Not one
Is wanting. Clerk record him guilty.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Now
The sentence!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Traitors hold!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Heard'st thou a scream?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: 'Tis the malignant wife of Fairfax.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No .
A greater far than she.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hold murderers!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Lead
Yon railing woman from her seat. My lord
Please you proceed.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Traitors here is my seat—
I am the Queen is my place, my state,
My lord & Sovereign—here at thy feet!
I claim it, with a prouder humbler heart,
A lowlier duty, a more loyal love,
Than when the false & glittering diadem
Encircled first my brow, a Queenly bride.
Put me not from thee! Scorn me not! I am
Thy wife.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh true & faithful wife! Yet leave me
Lest the strong armour of my soul, her patience,
Be melted by thy tears. Oh go! go! go!
This is no place for thee.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why thou art here —
Who shall divide us?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Force her from him guards!
Remove her !

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tremble ye, who come so near
As but to touch her garments ! Cowards! Slaves!
Though the King's power be gone, yet the man's strength
Remains unwithered. She's my wife ! my All!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: None thinks to harm the lady. Good my lord,
The hour wears fast with these slight toys.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: come
To aid ye not impede. If in this land
To wear the lineal crown, maintain the laws,
Uphold the insulted Church be crimes, then I
Am guilty, guiltier than your King ! 'Twas I
That urged the war—ye know he loved me
That prompted his bold councils , edged & whetted
His great resolves , spurred his high courage on
Against ye, rebels! I that armed my knight
And sent him forth to battle. Mine the crime .
Be mine the punishment . Deliver him
And lead me to the block. Pause ye? My blood
Is royal too. Within my veins the rich
Commingled stream of princely Medici
And regal Bourbon flows: 'twill mount as high,
'Twill stain your axe as red, 'twill feed as full
Your hate of Kings.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Madam, we wage no war
On women.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I have warred on ye, & now—
Take heed how ye release me!— is gentle
Patient & kind; he can forgive; but I
Shall roam a frantic widow through the world
Counting each day for lost that hath not gained
An enemy to England, a revenger
Of this foul murder.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Woman peace! The sentence!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yoursentence, bloody Judges ! As ye deal
With your anointed King, the red right arm
Of Heaven shall avenge him: here on earth
By clinging Fear & black Remorse, & Death,
Unnatural ghastly Death; & then the fire
The eternal fire where panting murderers gasp
cannot die, that deepest Hell which holds
The Regicide.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Peace! I have overlong
Forgotten my high office. Hence! or force
Shall rid us of thy frenzy. Knowst thou not
That curses light upon the curser's head,
As surely, as the cloud which the sun drains
the salt sea returns into the wave
In stormy gusts or plashing showers? Remove her.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh mercy! mercy! I'll not curse; I'll be
As gentle as a babe. Ye cannot doom him
Whilst I stand by. Even the hard headsman veils
His victim's eyes before he strikes, afeared
Lest his heart fail. And could ye, being men
Not fiends, abide a wife's keen agony
Whilst—I'll not leave thee Charles! I'll never leave thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is the love stronger than life, the love
Of woman. Henrietta listen. Loose
Thy arms from round my neck —Here is no axe—
This is no scaffold — We shall meet anon
Untouched, unharmed . I shall return to thee
Safe! safe! shall bide with thee—Listen, my Dear-One,
Thy husband prays, thy King commands thee Go!
Go! Lead her gently, very gently.
Now
I am ready. Speak your doom & quickly.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Death.
Thou art adjudged to die. Sirs, do ye all
Accord in this just sentence?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am ready.
To a grey head, aching with royal cares,
The block is a kind pillow. Yet once more—

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Silence ! The Sentence is pronounced; the time
Is past. Conduct him from the Court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not hear me ?
Me your anointed King? Look ye what justice
A meaner man may hope for.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why refuse
His death-speech to a prisoner? Whoso knoweth
What weight hangs on his soul ? Speak King & fear not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fear! Let the guilty fear ! Feel if my pulse
Flutter? Look if my cheek be faded? Harken
If my calm breathing be not regular
Even as an infant's who hath dropt asleep
Upon its mother's breast? As I lift up
This Sword, miscalled of Justice, my clear voice
Hoarsens nor falters not ! See I can smile
As thinking on the axe I draw the bright

Keen edge across my hand
! And yet for ye,

unclear.supplied: My subject judges, I could weep[.] I love ye;—
I would have been your father, but you [were]

l.del: This is a retribution. Fear!—Would thou ask

sp.l: What weight is on my soul. Fear!—Would ye ask
What weight is on my soul, I tell ye none
Save that I yielded once to your decree,
And slew my Faithfullest. Oh Strafford! Strafford!
This is a retribution!

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Better weep
Thy sins than one just holy act.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For ye
My subject-judges I might weep; for thee
Beloved and lovely country ! Thou wilt groan
Under the tyrant Many till some bold
And crafty soldier, one who in the field
Is brave as the roused lion, at the Council
Watchful and gentle as the couchant pard,
The lovely spotted pard, what time she stoops
To spring upon her prey; one who puts on,
win each several soul, his several sin,
A stern fanatic, a smooth hypocrite,
A fierce R e p ublican, a coarse buffoon,
Always a great bad man; till he shall come,
And climb the vacant & fix him there,
A more than King. Cromwell, if such thou know'st
Tell him the rack would prove an easier couch
Than he shall find that throne. Tell him the crown
On an Usurper's brow will scorch and burn,
As though the diamonded and ermined round
Were framed of glowing steel.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Hath His dread wrath
Smitten thee with frenzy?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell him, for thou know'st him,
That Doubt & Discord like fell harpies wait
Around the Usurper's board. By night, by day,
Beneath the palace roof, beneath that roof
More fair, the summer sky, fear shall appal
And D anger threaten, and all natural loves
Wither and die; till on his dying bed,
his time, the wretched traitor lies
Heartbroken. Then, for well thou know'st him, Cromwell,
fell
Hewn in my strength and prime, like a proud oak,
The tallest of the forest, that but shivers
His glorious top and dies. Oh! thou shalt envy,
In thy long agony, my fall, that shakes
On to my prison.

sp.speaker: Bradshaw.
sp.l: Lead the prisoner forth.

sp.speaker: Soldiers.
sp.l: Justice & Execution.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Good my comrades
Vex not a dying man with words. Full surely
He is possessed with a fierce Devil! The Wrath
Hath fallen upon him Harrison.

sp.speaker: Soldiers.
sp.l: To Justice
To Execution.

div.head:
Charles the First.
Act the Fourth.

div.stage: Scene— an apartment in Cromwell's h ouse.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: So my lord Broghill! We are shrewdly rid
Of one bold plotter. Now to strike at once
Ere fresh conspiracies—

sp.speaker: Cromwell.
sp.l: What mak'st thou here
Fair S on?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The l ords Commissioners refuse
To sign the warrant. He'll escape us yet.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Refuse! What all?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: No; Harrison & Marten
still hold firm.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Too few! too few!
Aye he'll escape. They'll treat. What say the traitors?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The most keep stubborn silence. Harrison
Is hoarse with railing.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Overhot! But that's
A fault may pass for virtue. Over-
Your modish sin. Weakness or treachery!
Peters or Judases! They'll treat.—
lies thy regiment?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: At Westminster.
One gleam of their bright swords, one stirring note
Of their war-trumpet, & these dastard Judges—
I'll seek them instantly.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Son thou mistak'st.
Foul shame it were, here in this Christian land
To govern by brute force, many hast thou?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: A thousand horse.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Or turn their very guards
Against the judges—We must keep unstained
The course of justice—Be they trusty?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Sir
I'll answer for them as myself.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Nay go not !
No force good s on! No force!
What wouldst thou? Speak.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: The Colonel Harrison sends me to crave
Your e xcellency's presence.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Aye ? I come.
the gallant
Whom thou saw here this morning?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir they passed me
At speed.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I come. No force good son ! Remember
This is a Christian land. We must keep pure
The j udgment seat. No force.
At speed! Ere now
They have crost the Thames at Kew. We are quit of one
Bold Cavalier. What said the Colonel?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Prayed
Your instant presence, & betwixt his teeth
Muttered Faint craven souls!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Fie! fie! to speak
Irreverently of such great-ones. Faint
And craven souls. Follow my son. Thou'lt find him
Heading his valiant Horse . Bid him be still
Till I send to him , still as night. And now
For ye wise Judges!

div.stage: Bradshaw, Harrison, Cook, Downes, Tichburne, Marten & other Judges.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Be ye all smit with palsy? Hang your arms
Dead at your sides that ye refuse to sign
The Warrant? Be ye turned Idolaters?
Rank worshippers of Baal?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: They refuse not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They parley, Sir, they dally, they delay.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: vantage ground,
The keen axe swinging o'er his head, to treat
With y our great prisoner.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Treat! Was yonder trial
A mummery, a stage-play, a farce? Oh blind
And stubborn generation!

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The whole people
Are struck with awe & pity. Each man's cheek
Is pale; each woman's eye is wet; each child
Lifts up its little hands, as to implore
Mercy for the poor King.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Captivity
And bondage will o'ertake them . They fall off
Like the revolted Tribes — Ægyptian bondage!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore so loud good Colonel? Sirs I shame
To have held ye waiting here , a sudden cause
I pray ye believe it earnest , hindered me.
Where is the W arrant? Have ye left a space
For my poor name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou wilt find room enow.
There!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: What unsigned? Harrison! He came hither
To crave your signatures.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I did my message
But these Philistines—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Do ye shame to set
Your names to your own deeds? Did ye not pass
This just and solemn sentence in the face of day
Before the arraigned King, the shouting people,
The M ajesty of Heaven?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Thou dost mistake us.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I crave your pardon Sirs. I deemed ye were
The J udges, the King's judges, the E lect
Of England, chosen by her godly Commons
As wisest, boldest, best. I did mistake ye.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Listen ere thou accuse us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Listen! S ign ;
And I will listen though your pleaded reason
Outlast Hugh Peter's S ermon.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Hear me first.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Well .

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: We have here Commissioners from Scotland
Praying our mercy on the King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: They gave him
Into our hands.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And they are answered Sir.
Thou know'st that Cromwell singly put them down
As they had been young babes.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The Pensionary—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Hath sent pressing missives; Embassies
From every court are on the seas; & Charles
Proffers great terms.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Have we not all?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: But he
Will give a fair security, a large
And general amnesty ; s o are we freed
From fear of after reckoning.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Master Cook
No wonder that a lawyer pleads to day
Against his cause of yesterday , if fee
To the height. But thou art not of us; thy part
Is o'er.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He will give large securities —
For what?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: The general safety , & our own ,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Safety ! S ay liberty! Securities.
Many large promises! An ye will trust
Ye may be Earls & Marquesses, and portion
This pretty I slet England as a M anor
Amongst ye. Shame ye not to think a bribe
Might win your souls from freedom?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: From the Lord!
Would ye desert h is people? sell for gain
His cause .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Hush! Hush! None thinketh to forsake
The C ause .

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Let Bradshaw sign. What need more names
Than the Lord President's?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: I am ready Sirs
An ye will follow me. The Instrument
Were else illegal. When ye are prepared,
Speak.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: My good M asters ye remember me
Of a passage of my boyhood.
Deem me not
A light unmeaning trifler . R ecollect
How Nathan spake to David. (aloud) Being a child
Nutting with other imps in the old copse
At Hinchinbroke, we saw across a wide
But shallow stream one overhanging hazel
Whose lissome stalks were weighed by the rich fruitage
Almost into the water. As we stood
Eyeing the tempting boughs, a shining nut
Fell from its socket, dimpling wide around
The dark clear mirror. At that sight one bold
And hardy urchin, with myself, no less
In those young days a daring wight, at once
Plunged in the sparkling rivulet. It rose
Above our ancles, to our knees, half up
Our thighs, & my scared comrade i ' the midst
Of the stream turned roaring back, & gained the bank
Nutless & wet amidst the scoffing shouts
Of the small people.

sp.speaker: Marten.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why I bore
My course right on & gained the spoil. Sirs, we
Have plunged knee - deep in the waters , are mid - way
The stream ,—w ill ye turn now & leave the fruit
Ungathered recreants , or hold boldly on
And win the holy prize of freedom? Give me
The W arrant. (signs) So! M ethinks an it were not
Over ambitious, & that's a sin ,
My homely name should stand alone to this
Most righteous scroll. Follow who list ! I've left
A space for the Lord President.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: I'll fill it
With an unworthy name.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Now swell the roll,
Swell the roll fast! Where goest thou Marten? None
Shall stir till he hath signed. Thou a ripe scholar
Not write thy name! I can write mine i' the dark,
And oft with my sword-point have traced in air
The viewless characters in the long hour
Before the joy of battle. Shut thine eyes
And write thy name! Anywhere! See,
Nay, ,
Stand still —See! See! how fair & clerkly! Yet
This parchment is the smoother.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hold thee sure
I'll pay thee General.

sp.speaker: Bradshaw.
sp.l: Why he hath marked thee
Like a fresh- ruddled sheep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll pay thee.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sign.

sp.speaker: Marten.
sp.l: Willingly, joyfully!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why so. Where goes
Our zealous alderman? I deemed to see
His name the first.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: He fears the c ity's safety,
Full, as he says, of the King's friends.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: He fears!
They be bold men who fearlessly do own
Their fears , I dare not. Fear! Sir didst thou come
By water hither?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: And didst thou meet
No soldiers on thy way?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: Many. The streets
Are swarming with them.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Were they silent?

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: No ,
They called aloud for execution.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Say
For justice & for execution. Marry
My bold Dragoons know not the new state trick
To separate the words. Well! are not they
A nearer fear? Sign boldly.

stage.emph: (Cromwell Marten and Downesadvance to the front)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They flock fast.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis time ; for plots are weaving round about us
Like spider's nets in Au gust . But this morning
I swept one web away. Lord Broghill—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What!
Hath he been here?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Is he discovered?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir
I have a slow-hound's scent to track a traitor —
He's found , & he's despatched.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: To Ireland
With a commission 'gainst the rebels. 'Tis
An honest soldier who deserves to fight
He but mistook his side;
The Queen beguiled him, & the knightly sound
Of L loyalty. But tis an honest soldier ;
He will prove faithful.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How didst win him?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: How?
A word of praise, a thought of fear. How do men
Win traitors? Hark ye, , Lord Broghill left
A list of the King's friends amongst us here;—
Grave seeming r oundheads, bold & pious soldiers,
High officers—I marvel not ye look
Distrustfully—one of renown, a Colonel
A Judge too — Downes hast thou signed yonder Warrant?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What was the plan?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Go sign I say.—The plan ?
A sudden rescue, to o'erpower the guard.—
Ha! Ingoldsby!

div.stage: ( seizing one of the Judges & going with him to the table )

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Nay, man, if thou be questioned
Some dozen years hence, say that I forced thee, swear
Thy wicked K insman held thy hand. Aye N ow
The blank is nobly filled, & bravely! now
I know ye once again, the pious Judges
The E lect & godly of the land .—
Haste to my son , bid him disband his force
The peril is gone by.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What peril?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ye
That are assembled here should lift your voice
for quick deliverance
From hidden danger; y e knew nought of this
Great jeopardy, nor need ye know. Give thanks ;
And question not. Ye are safe.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Art sure of that?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Did ye not hear me even now take order
The guard should be dispersed? Question no more.
Ye are so safe that this slight parchment, Sirs,
May be your shield.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The deed is incomplete.
It hath no date.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ha well reminded . W rite

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.l: Tomorrow? T hat were sudden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Why so we must be. There be plots astir
And speed is our best safety.—Thou hast signed —
Is not thy name among us? —I must haste
To overtake the hour. 'Tis still unsealed ;
Bradshaw.

sp.speaker: Tich.
sp.l: What intends
The General?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Question not of that. A taper!
Your seals, my Lords Commissioners! Your seals!

div.stage: Enter the King leading in the Princess Elizabeth & the Duke of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here we may weep at leisure. Yon fierce ruffian
Will scarce pursue us here. Elizabeth
I thought I had done with anger, but the ruffian
Who gazed on thee awhile, with looks that seemed
To wither thy young beauty, & with words—
My child! my child! And I had not the power
To shield mine own sweet child!

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: I saw him not;
I heard him not ; I could see none but thee;
Could hear no voice save thine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When I am gone
Who shall protect thee !

sp.speaker: Glou.
sp.l: I shall soon be tall;
And then—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor boy! Elizabeth be thou
A mother to him ! Rear him up in peace
And humbleness. Show him how sweet Content
Can smile on dungeon floors; how the mewed lark
Sings in his narrow cage. Plant P atience, dear - ones,
Deep in your hearts.
Herbert where stays the Queen?
Still on that hopeless quest of hope, though friends
Drop from her fast as leaves in Autumn .

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Sire
Her Grace is absent still ; But General Cromwell
Craves audience of your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Admit him.
Wipe off those tears Elizabeth. Resume
Thy gentle courage. Thou art a Princess.
Sir
Thou seest me with my children. Doth thine errand
Demand their absence?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No. I sent them to thee
In c hristian charity. Thou hast not fallen
Amongst the Heathen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Howsoever sent
It was a royal boon. My heart hath ached
With the vain agony of longing love
To look upon those blooming cheeks, to kiss
Those red & innocent lips, to hear the sound
Of those dear voices.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir, 'twas meet to send them they came,
That thou might see them once again, might say—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewell! I can endure the word—a last
Farewell! I have dwelt so long upon the thought
The sound seems nothing. Ye have signed the sentence .
Fear not to speak Sir ?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis a heavy task heavy duty—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye havesigned. And the day?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What!
So soon? And yet I thank ye. Speed is mercy.
Ye must away, poor children.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Nay the C hildren
May bide with thee till nightfall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take them !

sp.speaker: Children.
sp.l: Oh! No! No! No!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dear ones I go
On a great journey. Bless ye once again,
My children! We must part. Farewell !

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Oh father
Let me go with thee!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know thou whither?

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Yes;
To Heaven. Oh take me with thee! I must die
When the tree falls the young buds wither. Take me
Along with thee to Heaven! Let us lie
Both in one grave!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now bless ye! This is death !
This is the bitterness of love !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Fair child
Be comforted.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did thou not pat her head?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She minded me, all in her innocent tears,
Of one in mine own dwelling.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast daughters .
Be kind to her.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And the poor boy ,
He comes not near the throne. Make not of him
A puppet King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I think not of it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take them
Good Herbert! And my wife—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She shall be safe;
shall home to France unharmed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now F are ye well!—
Cromwell come back —No again,
No more of parting ! B less them! B less them! See
The girl hath wept away
Her tears & pants & shivers like a fawn
Dying. Oh for some gentle face to look on
When she awakes or she will surely die

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: She shall be cared for.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are they gone? quite gone?
I might have kissed them once again, have charged them
To love each other —No ! 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thou bad'st me
Remain. What is thy will?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be kind to them !
Be very kind to them .

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Have I not promised?
Was this what thou would say?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No But the love,
The o'ermastering love—that was the death-pang Cromwell,
Thou wilt be kind to them?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Would have me swear?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay swear not lest I doubt. I will believe thee.
And for the human pity thou hast shown,
The touch of natural ruth, I prithee take
My thanks.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I would have saved thee. By this hand,
This sinful hand, I would have saved thee, King,
Had thou flung by yon bauble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is One
Who reads all hearts ; one who pursues all crimes,
From silver-tongued & bland H ypocrisy
To treasonous murder. The unspoken thought
And the loud lie, & the accursed act
Mount to His throne together. Tempt Him not !
I know thee for the worker of this deed,
And knowing pardon thee , —but tempt not Him!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thy blood be on thy head! I would have saved thee ;
Even now the thought stirred in me. Pardon, Lord,
That gazing on the father's agonies
My heart of flesh waxed faint, & I forgot
Thy glory &and Tt hy cause, the suffering saints .
Freedom! Thy blood be on thy head !

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So be it !

div.head:
Charles the First
Act the Fifth.

div.stage: The King, starting from his couch , Herbert asleep.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Herbert! Is't time to rise? He sleeps. What sounds
Were those that roused me? Hark again! The clang
Of hammers! Yet the watch burns; the day
Is still unborn. This is a work of night,
Of deep funereal darkness. Each loud stroke
Rings like a knell, distinct, discordant, shrill,
Gathering, redoubling, echoing round my head,
Smiting me only with its sound amid
The slumbering city, tolling in mine ear—
A passing bell! It is the scaffold. Heaven
Grant me to tread it with as calm a heart
As I bear now. His sleep is troubled.Herbert!
'Twere best to wake him. Herbert! Rouse thee man!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Did your Grace call?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye; we should be today
Early astir. I've a great business toward ;
To exchange the K ingly wreath, my crown of thorns,
For an eternal diadem — to die—
And I would go trim as a bridegroom. Give me
Yon ermined cloak. If the crisp nipping frost
Should cause me shiver, there be tongues would call
The wintery chillness Fear. Herbert my sleep
Hath been as soft & balmy as young babes
Inherit from their blessed innocence
Or hardy peasants win with honest toil.

When I awoke thy slumbers were perturbed,At the beginning of this line in the manuscript with a pencilled left square bracket around the “W” in “When”, Mitford marks the start of a long suggested deletion of 34 lines with the following pencilled note in the left margin: This perhaps better omitted. The suggested deletion runs to the end of this following dialogue about Herbert’s dream, to the King’s line below in the manuscript, “A thrice blessed omen!”
Unquiet.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Vexed my liege with dreams.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: So please you, Sire, demand not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost thou think
A dream can grieve me now? Speak.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Thrice I slept,
And thrice I woke, & thrice the self-same vision
Haunted my fancy. Seemed this very room,
