This dim and waning taper, this dark couch,
Beneath whose crimson canopy reclined
A form august & stately. The pale ray
Of the watch light dwelt upon his face, & shewed
His paler lineaments, where M ajesty
And manly Beauty & deep trenching T hought,
And Care, the W rinkler, all were blended now
Into one calm & holy pensiveness
Softened by slumber. I stood gazing on him
With weeping love, as one awake; when sudden
A thick & palpable darkness fell around,
A blindness, & dull groans & piercing shrieks
A moment echoed; then they ceased, & light
Burst forth & musick such as the flood
Of day-spring at the dawning, rosy sparkling,
An insupportable brightness ! A nd i'th' midst,
Over the couch a milk white dove, which soared
Right upward, cleaving, with its train of light
The Heavens like a star. The couch remained
Vacant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh that the spirit so may pass!
So rise! Thrice did thou say?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Three times the vision
Passed o'er my fancy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A thrice blessed omen!
sp.note: Here Mitford indicates the end of a long suggested deletion of 34 lines with a pencilled right square bracket after “omen!”, and the following pencilled note: better omit to here. The suggested deletion begins above with the King’s observation of Herbert’s restless sleep and inquiry into his dream, above with “When I awoke, thy slumbers were perturbed.”
sp.l: Herbert joy
Content & peaceful as the Autumn sun
When, smiling for awhile on the ripe sheaves
And kissing the brown woods, he bids the world
A calm G oodnight. Bear witness that I die
In charity with all men . A nd take thou,
My kind & faithful servant, follower
Of my evil fortunes true & tender, take
All that thy master hath to give—his thanks,
His poor but honest thanks ! Another King
Shall better pay thee. Weep not. Seek the Bishop;
And if thou meet with that fair C onstancy,
My mournful Henrietta, strive to turn
Her steps away till—I'm a coward yet
And fear her lest she come to plunge my thoughts
In the deep fountain of her sad fond tears,
To win me—Ha! C an that impatient foot,
That hurrying hand which shakes the door—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My Charles!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Haste to the Bishop !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Charles!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Already here!
Thou did arms last night,
Dizzy & faint & spent, as the tired martlet,
Midway her voyage deck
And slumbers through the tempest. I kissed off
The tears that hung on thy fair eyelids, blessing
Thy speechless weariness, thy weeping love
That sobbed itself to rest. Never did M other
Watching her fevered infant, pray for sleep
So calm, so deep long as I besought
Of Heaven for thee, when half unconscious, yet
Moaning & plaining like a dove, they bore thee
With gentle force away. And thou art here
Already! W akened into sense & life
And the day s agony !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Here! I have been
To Harrison, to Marten, to Lord Fairfax,
To Downes, to Ireton . E ven at Bradshaw's feet
I've knelt to day. Sleep ! S hall I e v er sleep
Again!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: At Bradshaw's feet ? Oh perfect love
How can I chide thee? Yet I would thou had spared
Thyself & me that scorn.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Do h unters scorn
The shrill cries of the lioness, whose cubs
They've snared, although the f orest-Queen approach
Crouching? Do seamen scorn the forked lightning
Albeit the storm-cloud weeps They strove to soothe;
They spake of pity; one of hope.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas!
All thy life long the torturer H ope hath been
Thy M aster!—Yet if she can steal an hour
From grief— W hom dost thou trust?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thyself & Heaven
And a relenting woman. Wrap thyself
Close in my cloak—Here! H ere!— T o Lady Fairfax!
She's faithful , she'll conceal thee ! Take the cloak !
Waste not a point of time, not while one grain of sand
Runs in the glass ! Dost fear its shortness? See
In happier days thou hast floated me for height
And stooped in pretty mockery to look
Up at my eyes. On with the cloak! Begone!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My post is here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To perish!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No ;
To live to a blest old age with thee in freedom !
Away my Charles, my King! I shall be safe—
And if I were not, could I live if thou—
Charles thou wilt madden me. 'Tis the first boon
I ever craved , & now by our young loves,
By our commingled griefs, a mighty spell,
Our smiling children , & this bleeding land,
Go , I conjure thee, go!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Begone! or I will speak such truth— & truth
Is a foul treason in this land—will rain
Such curses on them as shall force them to lay
My head upon the block. Fly! Fly!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Dost see
Fierce soldiers crowded round as if to watch
A garrisoned fort, rather than one unarmed
Defenceless man, & thinkst thou I could win
A step unchallenged? Nor, though to escape
Were easy as to breathe, the vigilant guard
Smitten with sudden blindness, the unnumbered
And stirring swarms of this vast city locked
In charmed sleep, & darkness over all
Blacker than starless night, spectral & dim
As an eclipse at noon-tide , though the gates
Opened before me & my feet were swift
As the Antelope's, not then, if it but perilled
A single hair of friend or foe, would I
Pass o'er the threshold. In my cause too much
Of blood hath fallen. Let mine seal all. I go
To Death as to a bridal; thou thyself
In thy young beauty wast not welcomer
Than he. Farewell beloved wife! My chosen!
My dear one ! We have loved as peasants , sweetest,

Rather than Princes,
& have
been as fond as they,
As happy & as true. Now Fare thee well!
I thank thee & I bless thee. Pray for me,
My Henrietta !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Charles thou shalt be saved.
Talk not of parting. I'll to Fairfax . H e
Gave hope & hope is life.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Farewell!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: That word—
I prythee speak it not! me, lives
Like a serpent's hiss within mine ear, sho o ts through
My veins like poison, twines & coils about me
Clinging & killing. 'Tis a sound accurst,
A word of death & doom ! Why shouldst thou speak it?
Give me a ringlet of thy hair— No! no!
ot now! — Thou shalt not die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet wife
Say to my children that my last fond thought—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Last! Thou shalt live to tell them of thy thoughts
Longer than they or I to hear thee. Harken!
Promise thou wilt await me here . Let none—
They will not dare, they shall not. I but waste
The hour. To Fairfax, the good Fairfax! Charles
Thou shalt not die!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh fondest truest woman!
My matchless wife!— The pang is mastered now !
I am Death's conqueror.— My Faithfullest!
My Fairest! My most dear! I shall ne'er see
Those radiant looks again, or hear the sound
Of thy blythe voice, which was a hope, or feel
The thrilling pressure of thy hand, almost
A language, so the ardent spirit burned
And vibrated within thee .— I'll to prayer,
And chase away that image .— I'll to prayer —
And pray for thee sweet wife! I'll to my prayers.

div.stage: Scene—The Banqueting-house at Whitehall; glass folding doors opening on the scaffold, which is covered with black; the block axe & visible. Officers & other persons are busy in the back-ground. Cromwell giving directions. Ireton, Hacker, & Harrison meeting. Cromwell! behind.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Cromwell!—Good morrow Ireton . Whither goes
The General?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: To see that all be ready
For this great deed.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: He hath the eager step,
The dark light in his eye, the upward look,
The flush upon his cheek that I've marked in him
When marching to the battle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Doth he not lead
To day in a great combat, a most holy
And glorious victory?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.stage: (at the back of the s tage)
sp.l: Hast thou ta'en order
That soon as the head's off the Abbey bell
Begin to toll?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Look that the axe
Be keen & the hand steady. Let us have
No butchery.
sp.stage: (advancing to the front of the s tage.
sp.l: If he die not, we must perish—
That were as nothing ; but with us will die
The liberty for which the blood of saints
And martyrs hath been spilt, freedom of act
Of speech, of will of faith! Better one gr a y
Discrowned head should fall, albeit a thought
Before the time, than God's own people groan
In slavery for

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Whoso doubteth
But he shall die?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The soldiery that one of a high place,
Fairfax—But I believe it not. Hast thou
The w arrant Hacker?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Since when doth Fairfax
Dare to impugn the sentence of a free
And public court, of England , of the Great

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: All-Righteous Judge, who hath delivered him
Manifestly to us?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Will he dare oppose
Army & people? h e alone ?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Be sure
The good Lord General, howsoe'er some scruple
May trouble him, will play a godly part
In this sad drama.—Aye I have the w arrant .
It is addressed to thee. Thou must receive
The prisoner & conduct him hither.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.l: Hath
The hour been yet resolved?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Not that I hear.
Ha our great General! Well met my l ord!
We that are laden with this heavy burthen
Lacked your sustaining aid .

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Cromwell I too
Am heavy laden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: You look ill at ease;
'Tis this chill air, the nourisher of rheums,
The very fog of frost, that turns men's blood
To water.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: No ! the grief is here. Regret,
Almost remorse, & doubt & fear of wrong
Press wear ily upon me. Is this death
Lawful?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: His country's sentence, good my l ord,
May be thy warrant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: An anointed King!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A bloody tyrant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Yet a man, whose doom
Lies on our conscience. (to Cromwell) We might save the King
Even now at the eleventh hour . W e two
Hold the nice scales of life & death, & shall not
Fair M ercy sway the balance? Dost thou hear me?
Wilt thou not answer? Canst thou doubt our power?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: No. Man hath always power for ill. I know
We might desert our friends, betray our country,
Abandon our great cause, & sell our souls
To Hell .— We might do do this & more; might shroud
These devilish sins in holy names, & call them
Loyalty, Honour, Faith, Repentance . C heats
Which the great Tempter loves.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Yet he arken !
Bethink thee of thy fame!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Talk'st thou of fame
To me? I am too mean a man, too lowly,
Too poor in state & name to need abjure
That princely sin, & for my humbleness
I duly render thanks. Were I as thou—
Beware the lust of fame, Lord General !
Of perishable fame, vain breath of man !
Slight bubble, frailer than the ocean foam
Which from her prow the good ship in her course
Scattereth & passeth on regardlessly.
Lord General beware!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I am Lord General ,
And I alone by mine own voice have power
To stay this deed.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Alone?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I'll answer it
Before the Council.

sp.speaker: Crom.

stage.emph: (advancing to the front of the stage)

sp.l: Ha! A lone! C ome nearer !

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: What would st thou with me?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Yonder men are firm
And honest in the cause, & brave as steel;
Yet are they zealots, blind & furious zealots!
I would not they should hear us— B loody zealots!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Speak Sir ! we waste the hour.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I would confess
Relentings like thine own hear us not?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I joy to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Thou art one elect,
A leader in the land, a chosen vessel
And yet of such a mild & gracious mood,
That I, stern as I seem, may doff to thee
This smooth & governed mask of polity,
And shew the struggling heart perplexed & grieved
In all its nakedness. Yes ! I have known
The kindly natural love of man to man
His fellow , the rough soldier's shuddering hate
Of violent death save in the battle , lastly
A passionate yearning for that sweetest power
Born of fair Mercy.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Yet but now thou chidd'st me

And with a lofty scorn for such
a weakness.
The change is sudden.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Good my L ord I strove
And wrestled with each pitying thought as born
Of earthly pride & mortal sin. Full oft
We selves
Aiming at p higher virtues trample down
Fair shoots of charity & gentle love
Yet still my breast was troubled ; & since thou
Art moved by such relentings—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: And a promise
Made to my wife.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: A wise & pious lady!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Thou wilt then save the King?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Sir ! we must have
Some higher warrantry than our wild will
Our treacherous human will afore we change
The fiat of a nation. Thou art a man
Elect & godlyHarrison!— G o seek
The presence of the Lord. Perhaps to thee
A guiding answer a divine impulsion,
May be vouchsafed. Go with him Harrison!
Seek ye the Lord together.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair
And pious counsel.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Step apart awhile;
We will await ye here.
Now! N ow! B e quick!
Is the scaffold all prepared? The headsman waiting
With shrouded visage & bare arm? The axe
Whetted? Be ready on the instant. Where
Be guards to line the room, mute wondering faces,
A living tapestry, & men of place
To witness this great deed? A King should fall
Decked with the pageantries of Death, the clouds
That roll around the setting sun.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: If Fairfax
Return before he come—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Dost thou mistrust
Harrison's gift in prayer? The General's safe.
Besides I sent erewhile the Halberdiers
To guard Charles Stuart hither. Hacker'll meet
His prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: But should Fairfax—

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore waste
A word on such a waverer ?

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: What hath swayed him?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: His wife! his wife! The Queen hath seen again
That haughty dame, & her fond tears—

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: I marvel
That thou endur'st that popish witch of France
So near.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: I watch her. He must die . 'Tis borne
Upon my soul as what shall be. The race,
The name shall perish.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: Aye the very name
Of King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Of Stuart.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And of King.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: So be it.
Will Bradshaw never come?
Ah welcome! welcome!
Ye are late.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Yon living mass is hard to pierce
By men of civil calling. The armed soldiers
Can scantly force a passage for their prisoner.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: He comes?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: He's at the gate.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: What say the people

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The most are pale & silent, as a Fear
Hung its dull shadow over them; whilst some
Struck with a sudden pity weep & wonder
What ails them; & a few bold tongues are loud
In execration.

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: And the soldiers?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They
Are true to the good cause.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The righteous cause!
My friends & comrades ye are come to witness
The mighty consummation. See the sun
Breaks forth! The Heavens look down upon our work
Smiling! The Lord hath risen!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The King!

div.stage: Enter the King, Hacker, Herbert, a Bishop, g uards &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why pause ye?
Come on !

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.l: Sir , from thy s on.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My boy! My boy!
No, no, this letter is of life, & I
And life have shaken hands. My K ingly boy!
And the fair girl! I thought to have done with this —
But it so clings! Take back the letter !
Take it me faithful Herbert,
That last impatient word ! Forgive me !— Now Sirs
What see ye on that platform? I am as one
Bent on a far & perilous voyage, who seeks
To hear what rocks beset his track.— What see ye?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Only the black-masked headsman.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye he wears
His mask upon his face ; an honest mask !
What see ye more?

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Nought, save the living sea
Of human faces, blent into one mass
Of sentient various life; woman & man,
Childhood & infancy & youth & age
Commingled, with its multitudinous eyes
Upturned in expectation. Aweful gaze
Who may abide thy power!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shall look upward.
Why pause we here?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: why !!

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: May it please thee, Sir,
To rest awhile? Bring wine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I need it not.
Yes! fill the cup! fill high the sparkling cup!
This is a holiday to loyal breasts,
The King's accession day. Fill high! fill high!
axe
Have yet a privilege beyond the slow
And painful dying bed, & I may quaff
In my full pride of strength a health to him,
Whom in one short half hour my funeral knell
Proclaims my successor :— Health to my son!
Health to the King of England !— Start ye, Sirs,
To hear the word? Health to King Charles ! & peace
To this fair realm! And when that blessed time
Of rightful rule shall come, say that I left
For the bold traitors that condemned, the cowards
That not opposing murdered me — (I have won
So near the t hrone of Truth that true words spring
Unbidden from my lips say that I left
A pardon air all

A free &
royal pardon!—Prythee speed me
On my rough journey.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Wherefore crowd ye there?
Make way !

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thank thee Bishop
Beware the step.

stage.emph: Exeunt King, Herbert, Bishop, and guards. A pause.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Doth he address the people?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not so , h e kneels.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Twere fittest. Close the door
This wintery air comes chill, & the Lord President
Is of a feeble body.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: H ark !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: 'Tis one
Who must be stayed.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: The Queen?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Go stop her !
It were not meet that earthly loves should mingle
With yonder dying prayer. Yes! Still he kneels.
Hacker come hither ! If thou see a stir
Amongst the crowd, send for my horse , they're ready .
Or if men some feeble heart
Wax faint in the great cause — as such there be ! —
Or on the scaffold, if he cling to life
Too fondly not send a sinful soul
Before his time to his account good Bradshaw!—
But no delay! — Is he still kneeling?—Mark me
No idle dalliance Hacker! I must hence,
Lest Fairfax— No weak dalliance! No delay!
The cause ! the cause ! good Bradshaw!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Methought I heard her here she win
To Fairfax— H e must die, as Ahab erst,
Or Rehoboam ; or as that great H eathen
Whom Brutus loved & slew. None ever called
Brutus a murderer! And Charles had trial ,
'Twas more than Caesar had , free open trial,
If he had pleaded ; But the Eternal Wrath
Stiffened him in his pride. It was ordained
And I but an impassive instrument
In the Almighty hand ; an arrow chosen
From out the sheaf. If I should reign hereafter
Men shall not call me bloody bell!—
No—all is hush as midnight shall be
Tenderer of English lives. Have they forgot
To sound the bell? He must be dead.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Lord Fairfax!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: The Queen! the Queen!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: They told me he was here;
I see him not ; but I have wept me blind;
And then that axe, that keen bright edgy axe,
Which flashed across my eyeballs, blinding me
More than a sea of tears.—Here's one : fly,
If thou be man, and bid the H eadsman stay
His blow for one short hour hour
Till I have found Lord Fairfax! Thou shalt have
Gold, mines of gold. Fly! Save him! Save the King!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Peace! P eace! Have comfort!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Comfort! A nd he dies !
They murder him ! the axe falls on his neck !
The blood comes plashing ! Comfort!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Out alas!
I can hear nought of Fairfax, royal Madam .
Cromwell the Master-murderer!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh forgive her
She knows not what she says. If thou be Cromwell
Thou hast the power to rescue . See I kneel ,
I kiss thy feet. Oh save him! Take the crown ,
Take all but his dear life! Oh save him
And I will be thy slave! I a born Princess,
I Queen will be thy slave !

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Arise!
My Lady Fairfax lead this frantic woman
To where her children bide.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou wilt not make
My children fatherless? Oh mercy! m ercy!
I have a girl
That never learnt to smile, & she shall be
Thy handmaid; she shall tend thy daughters ; I,
That was so proud, offer my fairest child
To be thy bondwoman.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Raise her! Undo
These clasping hands ! I marvel
Thou canst endure to see a creature kneel
To one create.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: Out on thee H ypocrite!
Where lags my husband?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Save him ! save him

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Woman arise! Will this long agony
Endure forever?
sp.stage: Enter Ireton followed by Fairfax and Harrison
sp.l: Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: What means
This piercing outcry?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Fairfax! He is saved!
He is saved!

sp.speaker: Ire.
sp.l: The bell! the Abbey bell! Hark!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: There
The will of Heaven spake ; The King is dead.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Look to the Queen. Cromwell this bloody work
Is thine.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: This work is mine. For yon sad dame
She shall away to France. This deed is mine
And I will answer it. The Commonwealth
Is firmly 'stablished Ireton. Harrison,
The Saints shall rule in Israel. My Lord General
The army is thine own, & I a soldier
A lowly follower in the C ause. An X in ink appears here in another hand, likely to mark the end of the manuscript. This deed
Is mine.—
